content: I have thought of posting this from time to time. I expect nothing out of it but I have to get this off my chest. I hope you all will understand. When I graduated from high school I graduated at the top of my class, did a great job on the Asvaab(I hope that is right). I had to choose between college or the military. The Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines wanted me and were practically sitting on the doorstep begging. Now I was born with cataracts on both eyes and there was no guarantee that I would be accepted into the military, no I was not blind in any form. They were there, period paragraph. My problem was that I was the kid everyone at school beat up on, I was the one my family beat up on. It left me with a bad speech problem, worse than a stutter. Sometimes it was so bad I could not say anything, the worst was having to answer the phone..I couldn't. It appears that the problem I had was worse on phone activity. With that I got afraid that I would end up in worse shape emotionally if I went into the service and got some D.I. or the other recruits "interested in me". I knew that would just about be my end if you get my drift. In essence, I am saying that I was a coward. I was afraid to give myself the future I should have had. With 20/20 being hindsight I never should have gone to college. I got a degree, top 10 percent in my class, in Computer Science with Business Admin. I never found a job. Then my life really took a nose dive. I was unable to find real work, they wanted me to pay my loan back (I agreed to it and so they had their right) I just got by on welfare until I was blinded by some thugs owned by our slumlord.I have been on SSI since. Anyway, I just wanted to get my cowardice off my chest, and apologize for not being there when I probably should have been.

When I graduated from high school I graduated at the top of my class, did a great job on the Asvaab(I hope that is right). I had to choose between college or the military. The Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines wanted me and were practically sitting on the doorstep begging. Now I was born with cataracts on both eyes and there was no guarantee that I would be accepted into the military, no I was not blind in any form. They were there, period paragraph. My problem was that I was the kid everyone at school beat up on, I was the one my family beat up on. It left me with a bad speech problem, worse than a stutter. Sometimes it was so bad I could not say anything, the worst was having to answer the phone..I couldn't. It appears that the problem I had was worse on phone activity. With that I got afraid that I would end up in worse shape emotionally if I went into the service and got some D.I. or the other recruits "interested in me". I knew that would just about be my end if you get my drift. In essence, I am saying that I was a coward. I was afraid to give myself the future I should have had. With 20/20 being hindsight I never should have gone to college. I got a degree, top 10 percent in my class, in Computer Science with Business Admin. I never found a job. Then my life really took a nose dive. I was unable to find real work, they wanted me to pay my loan back (I agreed to it and so they had their right) I just got by on welfare until I was blinded by some thugs owned by our slumlord.I have been on SSI since. Anyway, I just wanted to get my cowardice off my chest, and apologize for not being there when I probably should have been. Interesting post, to say the least. I don't know if you're looking for answers or just venting. But, I'll respond. First, I don't consider you a coward for not joining for the reasons you listed. I can't imagine, the helpless feeling you must have had. We ahve all been scared in our lives, especially growing up. Secondly, you don't mention if you still have the stuttering problem or how old you are. Are you at an age, you can still enlist? While you are right, you would have been picked on a little in boot camp,(some people just don't grow up as quickkly), I think th eexperience would also, have built you up and given you more self confidence. If you're still at a decent age, think about going in either as enlisted or taking a commission. Talk to a recruiter. Thanks for sharing.

content: Everyone has different challenges in life and respond to them in different ways. Not joining the military doesn't make you a coward any more than simply joining makes you a hero. Stop beating yourself up. There are plenty of ways you can make a positive impact other than serving in the military. have you considered helping out with the USO? Serving those who serve may be rewarding for you. Good luck.
reply: Everyone has different challenges in life and respond to them in different ways. Not joining the military doesn't make you a coward any more than simply joining makes you a hero. Stop beating yourself up. There are plenty of ways you can make a positive impact other than serving in the military. have you considered helping out with the USO? Serving those who serve may be rewarding for you. Good luck.

content: quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: I just got by on welfare until I was blinded by some thugs owned by our slumlord.I have been on SSI since. Just wondering - how you happened onto this site and typed this message - ? Computer equipment for the unsighted has been around for over 30-years! I worked on the prototypes and production models (hardware/firmware/software) for one particular brand of computer peripherals that were primarily for persons stuck in wheelchairs and were any combination of sightless, speachless, deaf, all the way to paralyzed from the neck-down and confined to bed and wheelchair! While that brand name has long since disappeared (purchased absorbed multiple times over by other conglomerates), I have seen some of the resulting designs in the collectors section on Ebay (that'll make you feel your age). One of the best programmers I ever knew (sadly passed now) had been blind from childhood due to diabetes! His seeing eye dog would fall asleep and start barking due to dreams (gassy bugger too); rather than slow down the work, everybody was in a better, more productive frame of mind because of the dog (once the gas cleared). To the topic! If the story is accurately related, all I can say is that you made your decisions (as we all made ours) and you have to learn to live with the results; don't berate yourself over it and there's no reason to beat yourself up. Learn from it and move on! If you feel you were unproductive because of it, be productive now and make the lives of others better with the skills you've learned! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine
quote: Originally posted by greywolfghost: quote: I just got by on welfare until I was blinded by some thugs owned by our slumlord.I have been on SSI since. Just wondering - how you happened onto this site and typed this message - ?

While that brand name has long since disappeared (purchased absorbed multiple times over by other conglomerates), I have seen some of the resulting designs in the collectors section on Ebay (that'll make you feel your age). One of the best programmers I ever knew (sadly passed now) had been blind from childhood due to diabetes! His seeing eye dog would fall asleep and start barking due to dreams (gassy bugger too); rather than slow down the work, everybody was in a better, more productive frame of mind because of the dog (once the gas cleared). To the topic! If the story is accurately related, all I can say is that you made your decisions (as we all made ours) and you have to learn to live with the results; don't berate yourself over it and there's no reason to beat yourself up. Learn from it and move on! If you feel you were unproductive because of it, be productive now and make the lives of others better with the skills you've learned! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine
